message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest urinary retention, and the drug most commonly used to treat this condition is a parasympathetic agonist, such as Bethanechol, which stimulates the detrusor muscle of the bladder to contract and empty the bladder. Sympathetic agonists, such as epinephrine, would exacerbate urinary retention. Alpha-blockers and beta-blockers are used to treat other conditions, such as hypertension or benign prostatic hyperplasia, but not urinary retention.

Sympathetic agonists, alpha-blockers, and beta-blockers are not commonly used for this indication.

This helps to stimulate the detrusor muscle and increase bladder contraction, improving urine flow. Sympathetic agonists would have the opposite effect, while alpha-blockers and beta-blockers are not indicated in this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing urinary retention, which can be treated with a parasympathetic agonist such as Bethanechol. This medication increases bladder contraction and improves urination. Sympathetic agonists, alpha-blockers, and beta-blockers do not address the issue of urinary retention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has urinary retention, which suggests decreased bladder contractility. Parasympathetic agonists such as Bethanechol stimulate bladder smooth muscle to contract, thereby increasing bladder emptying. alpha-blockers relax the smooth muscle of the prostate and bladder neck to improve urine flow, while beta-blockers decrease heart rate and blood pressure. Sympathetic agonists increase bladder sphincter tone, making urination more difficult.

It stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system to increase bladder muscle contraction and decrease sphincter tone, enabling urination.
